title: Generating Loss-of-function iPSC Lines with Combined CRISPR Indel  Formation and Reprogramming from Human Fibroblasts
procedures: Designing guide RNA (gRNA) and sequencing primersUsing a genome browser (genome.ucsc.edu[href=http://genome.ucsc.edu/]), the first conserved exon in all transcript isoforms of the gene (unless an isoform specific LOF mutation is desired) should be identified and the sequence copied. This sequence can then be inserted into a guide RNA design tool such as crispor.tefor.net[href=http://crispor.tefor.net/] or crispr.mit.edu[href=http://crispr.mit.edu/]. Note: The most important determinate is the specificity score. Use the highest score possible. Our previously reported data had an average score of 88 (Tidball et al., 2017). Record the most likely off-target sites as well to potentially screen for off-target indels in iPSC lines. The crispr.mit.edu[href=http://crispr.mit.edu/] does not identify off-targets with highly repetitive sequences (triplet repeats). The second score to be aware of is the out-of-frame score. This is a calculated probability that any given indel formed at the cut site will be out-of-frame, thus resulting in a frame-shift mutation and loss-of-function (presumably). Our previously reported data had an average score of 63. Lastly, the efficiency score should be > 50 to ensure a high rate of indel formation. Our previously reported data had an average score of 59.The gRNA can be ordered as standard desalted oligo-nucleotides with the sequence CACCG- on the 5’ end of the forward sequence and AAACC- on the 5’ end of the reverse sequence. These provide the appropriate overhangs for insertion into the px330 (or related) plasmid as well as a G at the beginning of the gRNA to initiate transcription from the U6 promoter. Note: DO NOT include the PAM sequence (NGG) in the gRNA oligo design. Sequencing primers should be designed with a ~200 bp amplicon size that nearly evenly flanks the CRISPR cut site, if possible. The crispor.tefor.net[href=http://crispor.tefor.net/] site gives a good set of sequencing primers.

Confirm the melting temperature and specificity of these primers by using the NCBI primer blast site (www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/tools/primer-blast/[href=http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/tools/primer-blast/]) (be sure to use human genomic reference sequence). Restriction digest of the vector plasmidAdd the following to a 1.5 ml tube:2 µg px3305 µl Buffer 2.12 µl BbsI enzymeWater to 50 µl (add water to tube first)Perform the digestion overnight at 37 °C.On the following day, heat inactivate the mix at 65 °C for 20 min to stop the digestion reaction.Purify the cut plasmid using QIAGEN PCR purification kit. Elute the purified plasmid in water.Note: The PCR purification kit is more efficient than gel extraction in isolating the cut plasmid and removes the majority of the small cut piece. When performing ligation for the first time, use BbsI cut plasmid without insert as a control to confirm lack or near lack of colonies. Cut plasmid can be stored for several months at -20 °C.Use a NanoDrop Spectrophotometer to determine the concentration of the cut plasmid.Annealing the gRNA oligos to make a double-stranded insertAdd the following to a 1.5 ml tube:1 µl of Oligo1 (100 µM)1 µl of Oligo2 (100 µM)7 µl water1 µl of Buffer 2Anneal primers in a PCR thermocycler using the following program:Step 1: 95 °C for 5 minStep 2: Ramp at -0.1 °C/sec from 95 °C to 25 °CStep 3: 25 °C for 30 secStep 4: Hold at 4 °C.Dilute 1:250 in water before proceeding.Ligation reaction of cut vector plasmid and annealed gRNA insert.Add the following components to a 1.5 ml tube:100 ng of cut px330 plasmid from Step 22 µl of diluted oligo duplex from Step 3c4 µl of 5x T4 buffer1 µl of T4 ligaseWater to 20 µl.Incubate the ligation mix at room temperature for 2 h.

Bacterial transformation of CRISPR-gRNA ligated constructGently add 2 µl of ligation reaction into 50 µl of DH5α heat shock competent cells (on the ice). Mix by flicking the tube a few times.Place the tube on ice for 30 min.Heat shock the transformation mixture by placing the tube in a 42 °C water bath for 20 sec.Incubate the tube on ice for 2 min.Add 950 µl of SOC medium and place the tube in a shaker at 37 °C for 1 h at 200 rpm.Plate 40 µl and 400 µl of cells on to two LB plates containing 50 µg/ml ampicillin.Incubate the plates at 37 °C overnight.Sequencing clonesPick 3 clones (using P200 pipette tips) per transformation reaction and inoculate each into a 14 ml tube containing 2 ml of LB broth with 50 µg/ml ampicillin. Place the 14 ml tubes with inoculant in a shaker at 37 °C and grow the bacterial culture for 7 h (or until cloudy). Use QIAGEN Miniprep kit according to the manufacturer’s instructions to isolate plasmid from 1.5 ml of bacteria. Mix remaining 0.5 ml of bacterial cultures with 0.5 ml 50% glycerol and store in -80 °C freezer until obtaining sequencing results.Determine the concentration of the isolated plasmids using a NanoDrop Spectrophotometer. Concentrations should be > 15 ng/µl to ensure starting material is adequate for sequencing.Send samples for Sanger sequencing. Typically, the sample will be diluted to 1 ng/µl in ddH2O. Use 1 µM of LKO.1 5’ sequencing primer (5’-GACTATCATATGCTTACCGT-3’).Based on results from sequencing, pick a clone containing the gRNA sequence to set up for a maxi culture. Inoculate 0.1 ml from the miniprep culture (Step 6d) into 100 ml of LB-Amp in a conical flask for overnight culture in a shaker at 37 °C and 200 rpm.

Perform DNA isolation from overnight bacterial cultures using the Endotoxin-free QIAGEN Maxi prep kit according to the manufacturer’s instructions.Determine the concentration of the plasmid using NanoDrop.Fibroblast cultureChange fibroblast medium (see Recipes) every other day. Passage cells before they become fully confluent approximately every 4 days.Wash once with 10 ml of 1x PBS.Add 2 ml of 0.25% trypsin per 10 cm (for a 10 cm dish). Place in a 37 °C incubator for 5 min.Once the cells detach, add 8 ml of fibroblast media and transfer the cells to a 15 ml conical tube. Centrifuge at 100 x g for 5 min at room temperature. Add 10 ml of fresh fibroblast medium and split cells at a 1:3-1:6 dilution factor on to a new 10 cm dish and add enough additional medium to each plate for 10 ml total.Transfecting fibroblasts with CRISPR and reprogramming plasmids1-2 h prior to transfection, coat a 6-well plate with Matrigel diluted 100 µg/ml in ice-cold DMEM/F12. Add 1 ml per well and incubate at 37 °C.Aspirate medium from sub-confluent fibroblasts (confluency 80% or less). Wash once with 10 ml of 1x PBS.Add 2 ml of 0.25% trypsin and incubate at 37 °C for 5 min. Add 8 ml of fibroblast medium to the detached fibroblasts. Pipette up and down several times with 5 ml Serological pipette to ensure even single cell suspension.Perform cell count using a hemocytometer.Transfer 2.5 x 105 cells into a 15 ml conical tube and centrifuge at 100 x g for 5 min at room temperature.Pipette 250 µl of Buffer R into a sterile 1.5 ml tube. Add 2.5 µg each of the three reprogramming plasmid and 2.5 µg of CRISPR plasmid.

(100 µl of the suspension is for electroporation, 50 µl is to limit bubble formation in Neon tip, and 100 µl is for an additional electroporation if arcing occurs).Resuspend the fibroblast pellet in 250 µl of Buffer R containing reprogramming and CRISPR plasmids. Using a 100 µl Neon electroporation tip electroporate in the Neon at 1,650 V, 10 msec, 3 pulses.If the electroporation arcs (indicated by a flash of light and popping sound), discard the cell suspension in the tip and repeat with the extra 150 µl of cell suspension.Pipette successfully electroporated cell suspension from the Neon tip into 12 ml of warm fibroblast medium.Remove Matrigel solution from a Matrigel-coated 6-well plate, and add 2 ml of cell suspension to each desired well. Incubate the plate at 37 °C, and change fibroblast medium 18-24 h later. Three days after plating, change the medium to TeSR-E7 reprogramming medium.Replace TeSR-E7 medium daily.‘Pick-able’ colonies appear between 15-20 days after electroporation (see Figure 2).imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20180330/20180330004948_3853.jpgFigure 2. iPSC reprogramming timeline. The day 21 image is good for picking because of the well-defined margins, relative circularity, and lack of nearby colonies. Scale bars = 400 µm.Picking iPSC colonies Note: Typical yield will be ~20-40 colonies per well. If the number is substantially lower, this may indicate the starting fibroblast cultures were suboptimal (late passage, chromosomal abnormality, etc.). If the number is substantially higher, a dilution error may have occurred during the electroporation and single clones will be difficult to obtain. 1-2 h prior to picking, coat a 96-well plate with Matrigel diluted 100 µg/ml in ice-cold DMEM/F12. Add 60 µl to each well and incubate at 37 °C.Immediately before picking colonies, remove Matrigel solution and add 100 µl of mTeSR1 with 10 µM ROCK inhibitor (Y-27632).

In a HEPA workstation containing an inverted cell culture microscope (4x objective), pick individual colonies by dissecting with a 200 µl pipette tip on a micropipettor. After lifting the colony from the dish, remove the colony piece (or pieces) with the pipette in 50 µl volume, and place in one well of the 96-well plate. Note: Use standard 200 µl pipette tips, gel-loading tips or similar tips with small bore size will likely shear the colony too much. An excellent video of this technique can be found at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B0lXzsHIcK8[href=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B0lXzsHIcK8]. Bias picking toward round isolated colonies to decrease the risk of picking merged colonies leading to heterogeneous genotypes. (see Figure 2)Note: With typical reprogramming efficiency, 10-20 colonies can easily be picked from each well. Picking can be performed on consecutive days; however, do not pick from the same well of the 6-well plate on multiple days since secondary colonies could form from leftover pieces of picked colonies.Change media to mTeSR1 without Y-27632 daily.Note: Use an 8- or 12-channel multichannel pipette for Steps 10-15. Use disposable pipette basins to hold medium and solutions as well as for collecting waste. Passaging 96-well plates of iPSC clonesPassage 96-well plates when the majority of wells are at or near 100% confluency. Coat each new plate with 60 µl of 100 µg/ml Matrigel diluted in ice-cold DMEM/F12 media per well. Incubate plates for 1-2 h in a cell culture incubator.Aspirate all media from 96-well plate of cells using the 8-channel aspiration attachment. Wash the plate once with 150 µl of 1x PBS.Aspirate and add 30 µl of room temperature Accutase to each well of the plate. Incubate for 5 min in the cell culture incubator.Add 210 µl of mTeSR1 containing 10 µM ROCK inhibitor, Y-27632 to each of the wells.

Aspirate the Matrigel from previously coated plates.Transfer 50 µl of cells to the corresponding well of each new plate to be generated. After transferring the cells, add 100 µl of additional mTeSR1 with 10 µM ROCK inhibitor to each well to further dilute the Accutase. The cell confluency 24 h later should be between 10-30%.Isolating genomic DNA from 96-well plate using ZR-96 Quick gDNA kit from ZymoRemove medium and wash once with 100 µl of PBS.Add 300 µl of Genomic Lysis Buffer and incubate at room temperature for 10 min.Pipette lysate into Silicon-A Plate placed on a Collection plate.Using the plate adapters, centrifuge the plate at 2,500 x g for 5 min.Note: Be sure to properly balance centrifuge if only using 1 plate.Add 200 µl of DNA Pre-Wash Buffer to each well and centrifuge at 2,500 x g for 5 min. Discard flow through.Add 300 µl of g-DNA Wash Buffer to each well and centrifuge at 2,500 x g for 5 min. Discard flow through.Centrifuge dry at 2,500 x g for 5 min to remove any residual buffer.Place the Silicon-A Plate over the Elution plate. Add 40 µl of DNA Elution Buffer or water and incubate for 5 min at room temperature.Centrifuge at 2,500 x g for 5 min.Check that DNA was purified by a NanoDrop Spectrophotometer.PCR to amplify the target regionFor each 25 µl reaction mix, combine the following in a 1.5 ml Eppendorf tube:12.5 µl of GoTaq 2x Master Mix0.1 µl of 100 µM of each primer10.3 µl of Molecular Biology grade waterAdd 23 µl of the mixture to each well of a 96-well PCR plate or 8-well PCR tube strip for PCR.Add 2 µl of the template to each PCR well.Use optimized PCR annealing temperature and standard GoTaq protocol to perform the PCR.

Use a 2 min denaturing step at 95 °C followed by 40 cycles of the following: 95 °C for 30 sec, optimized annealing temperature for 30 sec, and 72 °C for 30 sec. Finally, a step of 72 °C for 5 min will finish incomplete extension of the PCR products.Purifying PCR products with ZR-96 DNA Sequencing Clean-Up Kit (Zymo)Add 240 µl of Sequencing Binding Buffer to PCR reactions.Transfer the mixture to Zymo-Spin IB-96 plate on a collection plate.Centrifuge at 2,500 x g for 5 min.Add 300 µl of Sequencing Wash Buffer to each well. Centrifuge at 2,500 x g for 5 min.Add 20 µl of water to each well and mount plate onto 96-well PCR plate.Centrifuge at 2,500 x g for 5 min.Purified PCR products on the 96-well plate can be sealed and stored at -20 °C.Run 5 µl of the purified PCR products mixed with 1 µl of 6x loading dye on a 2% agarose gel containing 1x GelRed Nucleic Acid Stain. Separate bands by electrophoresis in 1x TBE buffer at 100 V for 1-2 h and check for correct amplicon size using a gel imager. Quantifying DNA concentrations using PicoGreen Note: Alternatively, several wells could be quantified using the NanoDrop Spectrophotometer; however, the Zymo kit has a tendency for high 230 nm peaks making DNA quantification difficult. Thaw Quant-IT PicoGreen dsDNA Assay Kit components.Prepare 1x TE buffer by adding 1 ml of 20x TE buffer with 19 ml of water.Dilute PicoGreen 1:200 in 1x TE buffer (50 µl of diluted PicoGreen per well).Make a set of DNA concentration standards by serial diluting the DNA standard to 5, 1, 0.2, 0.04, and 0 ng/µl in 1x TE buffer.In a clear 96-well plate, add 50 µl of diluted PicoGreen to 15 wells. Add 50 µl of each standard in triplicate.

After 5 min, use a fluorescence plate reader to measure the fluorescence with an excitation of ~480 nm and emission of ~520 nm.Make a standard curve by inputting the standard DNA concentrations and fluorescence intensities into side-by-side columns in Excel. Generate an XY scatter-plot graph, right click on a data-point and select ‘Add Trendline’. In the ‘Options’ tab, select ‘Display equation on chart’. Record the equation. Note: If the graph is not linear, delete data-points in the non-linear regions and only use the standard curve equation for samples having fluorescence readings in the linear region. Add 50 µl of diluted PicoGreen to each well of a 96-well plate.Add 45 µl of 1x TE to each well.Add 5 µl of DNA from Step 13.Read on the plate reader and quantify the concentration using the equation generated in Step 14h and multiplying by 10. Sanger or Next-Gen sequencingThe PCR products can now be sequenced. Sanger sequencing is economical; however, the indels will cause overlapping peaks. These can be used to identify mutations using a program like Mutation Surveyor (Softgenetics.com[href=https://softgenetics.com/]) or manually to identify the indels formed. A less labor-intensive analysis solution is the use of Next-Gen sequencing. Samples can be submitted to the MGH (Massachusetts General Hospital) DNA Core for CRISPR Sequencing analysis. Briefly, barcoded Next-Gen sequencing adaptors are added to the ends of each sample and multiplex. 100 bp sequencing reads in the forward and reverse direction are performed. Each DNA species is then quantified as a percentage of total reads for each barcode, and aligned sequences with the percentage are listed for each sample.Suggested characterization stepsTest for episomal vector integration using qPCR for plasmid DNA. G-band karyotyping or SNP microarray to test for genomic abnormalities.CRISPR off-target PCR and sequencing for highest off-target site scores from the gRNA design tool.

This can be done for exonic and intronic or exonic-only off-targets. Test for mycoplasma contamination using myco-specific primers on cell lysates. Making frozen stock iPSC vialsNote: The most important aspect for the high viability of frozen iPSC is maintaining large colonies. Minimize pipetting whenever possible and use a larger scrapper to minimize colony breaking. Aspirate medium from iPSC culture in 1 well of 6-well plate that is ~50% confluent (this is higher than optimal for normal passaging but increases viability when freezing).Wash 1x with 2 ml of 37 °C DMEM/F12.Aspirate, add 1 ml of 37 °C DMEM/F12, and add 1 ml of cold 2 U/ml Dispase solution.Incubate at 37 °C for 8 min.Aspirate and wash 1x with 2 ml of 37 °C DMEM/F12.Add 2 ml of mTesr1 medium and scrap into the medium.Pipette gently into a 15 ml centrifuge tube and centrifuge at 50 x g for 3 min in a 15 ml conical tube.Aspirate medium and add 1 ml of mFreSR. Pipette gently into a 1.5 ml cryovial, place into a CoolCell cell freezing container, which is then placed in a -80 °C freezer overnight. Transfer cryovials into a liquid nitrogen storage tank the next day.
